content:
I assume you added a pop mail account. It will just be included in the global inbox in local folders by default. Only IMAP accounts get their own entry and that is because each folder is syncronised to the server, not for any other specific reason.

You can force the issue to have a fully formed account with it's own folders by changing the settings in the advanced button in account settings > server setting to use it's own inbox. Personally I like only having one inbox to look at and one sent folder.

Personally I dropped using Outlook about 2004. As soon as Microsoft introduced their ribbon toolbar, Office went with it. I have not looked back except to do occasional projects in Excel building templates and macros, so I struggle when folks compare with outlook. I have no frame of common reference in that product to refer to.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I have to wonder if the actual email is not correctly encrypted. Email uses what are called media types to identify the content of attachments at the time they are composed and this information goes with the email.

Then there are ancillary data types that Excel "claims" that are actually text data. So with that knowledge, the first thing to do it have a look at the message source (ctrl+U) looking for where the attachment is defined.

You will see a block that looks like the following, somewhere in the body of the email source. The following is for a PDF file attachment, but it illustrates what you are looking for. 

Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="INV-AUS-2388174.pdf" Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64 Content-Type: application/pdf; name="INV-AUS-2388174.pdf"

I have a feeling when you find this block the content type will not be one of the registered Excel media types; application/vnd.ms-excel application/vnd.ms-excel.addin.macroEnabled.12 application/vnd.ms-excel.sheet.binary.macroEnabled.12 application/vnd.ms-excel.sheet.macroEnabled.12

But instead something like text/csv or csv-schema which would explain the predilection for text based applications to handle the data.

But please have a look and report back what you find.
creator: MattAuSupport

creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thunderbird stores information about emails in a number of places. There is a global index/database that the full test search uses.

There is a folder index that is mostly used to populate the lists in the user interface Then there are the actual email storage files.

The first of the things you mention is the data is in the full text database for searching. The second conversation uses the second data source, the folder index, and the display of the mail is when the last item in the set, the mail storage file, is interrogated to retrieve the email from the location stored in the folder index. It is coming up blank.

This would indicate that in all probability the first two items are "out of date" and the emails are no longer held in the folder. I have to ask, can you display the content of any emails in the same folder? That arrived after the missing ones? or before?
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
At this point, and following a recent failure on my own system, I would suggest you physically remove the MSF that the system uses to populate the user interface.

Unfortunately I do not know where that file will be located as I do not know if your account is IMAP or POP, or when the mail provider is as the contents of an account are stored in a file directory that is named for the mail server name. So i have to ask more questions, or try and write a generic "how to" I tried that many years ago and it was not good, but here goes again.

  1. Go to the account settings page of the account. (Right click the account name in the folder pane)
  2. Select the server settings for the account.
  3. The last thing in the server settings is a "local directory" entry.
  4. Click browse.
  5. Click in the path part of the open dialog that opens. (but not on any of the words. In a blank space at the end.) The format of the displayed text will change from the normal style and the displayed text will be highlighted.
  6. Right click and select copy
  7. Click on Close to dismiss the dialog without making any changes.
  8. Shut down Thunderbird.
  9. Using windows file explorer/manager again click in the path part of the window in the same manner used in the other dialog.
  10. When the path is highlighted right click and select paste and press enter.
  11. You are now in the storage location for that accounts emails and you should see and inbox.msf file ( I think you said the problem was with the inbox). Delete it.
  12. Close the file explorer and restart Thunderbird and see if things would better.

content: The files with no extension, named after folders, and accompanied by like-named .msf files, are mbox files, and contain the message content. Copy the mbox files (ignore the .msf files), renaming if necessary, to Mail/Local Folders in the active profile, with TB closed. Restart TB, and find the folders under Local Folders in the Folder Pane.

content:
The question was asked (with a question mark, I did not post an answer) because I do understand you are frustrated and because attempting to better understand your situation may more quickly lead to a solution. As a general rule, we do ask follow up questions to help requests such as yours.

If you looking for an edit & move function, I'm not aware that any such thing exists in Thunderbird. Also, a real Junk folder (named "Spam" or "Junk") should have a special icon which indicates it cannot be moved, renamed or deleted.

Perhaps a better set of questions is:

  • What was the original folder name, Junk or Spam?
  • You indicate you moved it, so that implies you see it somewhere. Where are you seeing it? A screen shot will suffice.
  • Does it still have a special icon? (I'll post it here)

content:
• Go to Account Settings > Junk Settings > change Destination and Retention to some folder other than Junk.
  • Empty your trash folder
  • Delete the Junk folder under Inbox
  • Create a new Junk (or Spam) folder under the Comcast account
  • Go to Account Settings > Junk Settings > change Destination and Retention to that new folder name

content:
I know nothing of macs, but with Windows, I have found that using the OS's file management features works best when unraveling a mess of profile problems. My approach is two-fold: Locate the message files/folders and copy them to Local Folders in the designated profile. Then, in thunderbird, read the messages and move to a more desirable profile for going forward. That also applies to POP account folders, such as inbox and sent folders. Attempting to merge actual profiles has been, for me, a downward spiral. Also, attempting to gather the messages into a working profile at the eml level would quickly evolve into an excess of detail.

Once this is cleared up, I suggest routine backups, as the profile situation you described emerged over a long period where there must have been occasional blips in updates.

content:
Ok, roughly, here would be my approach: - first, assuming all profiles are in the thunderbird\profiles folder, do a full backup in case of any mistakes later. - then, clear out and recreate a fresh thunderbird install. - now, in the mac file manager, browse the old profiles, looking for duplicate files. For example, if two profiles each have Mail\accountxyz\inbox and inbox.msf and the size and date are the same, those are duplicates and only one should be marked for saving. The intent in this phase is to eliminate as many possible duplicates as possible. Make a list of the ones that are clear duplicates to avoid wasting time in extracting them. - now, in the mac file manager, locate desired message folders in the first old profile. These are normally in sets of two (e.g., inbox, inbox.msf). Copy to the Mail\Local Folders folder in the new profile. - now, start Thunderbird and the folders should appear and be accessible. I suggest at this time to rename the folders as you probably want to merge their messages later with other message folders. - repeat the above for each of the old profiles, copying to Mail\Local folders, checking in thunderbird and then renaming. - once you finish this, you will have all the saved messages in local folders. If some are for the same account, you could here create a new local folder with the account name, and then copy appropriate messages from the several other folders into the one primary account. You can now delete those staging folders.

I probably omitted a few minor steps here and there, but I think I've identified the basic process. When done, be sure to do a full backup with Thunderbird NOT running.
creator: davidsk

content: I forgot a tip: omitting the msf file works best if you will be renaming the staging files.
creator: davidsk

content:
I will take your word for the IONOS folk not limiting concurrent IMAP connections, but they would be very unusual in that decision.

Perhaps log the imap connection and see what it is all about. https://wiki.mozilla.org/MailNews:Logging

But before I did that, I would be looking at the error console (ctrl_Shift+J. This is a rather messy place as every error or warning is logged for all actions and a lot of it is really irrelevant. So the first thing to do is clear the console using the trash button on it's toolbar.

Now try and download the mail from the imap account. What do you get logged in the console? Other than what you already know. It is reporting a possible lack of available connections.

It may be an issue with third party software like an antivirus that has it's own limit on connections it can scan. Perhaps try without any email scanning.

content:
In all cases that I've ever come across that message means there are limits on concurrent connections to server when using imap.

Those connections mean all connections to server accumulated from all computers, phones etc. The normal method of a fix is to set the cached connections in Thunderbird to 1. Then exit Thunderbird. Repeat on each computer. Do not restart any Thunderbird until all computers have been set to cache connection = 1 and closed down. Sometimes it can take a few minutes for server to recognise connection has closed.

I did find out that ionos do have limits on ftp https://www.ionos.co.uk/help/hosting/setting-up-and-managing-ftp-access/ftp-error-messages-explained/

Are you using ionos with a google workspace or microsoft exchange package?

I suggest you check in your GMail account online re what they are offering as IMAP folders.

Both of those folders have a drafts flag set or they would not have the pink icon and for IMAP account things like this should "just map" so I am rather leery of making the following suggestion to soon in the process of trying to fix it.

When all else fails there is an addon. https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/folderflags/?src=ss

The addon can be used to remove the special flag on the folder and once that is done it will delete.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Just as an aside, check all account in account settings for what folder is set for drafts. As these can be set to another accounts folders it might be some sort of hiccup in that.

content:
For us to better investigate this issue, we will need some more information. What error messages do you see? Verbatim please.

Could you please do the following?

  1. Open the menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information, then click Copy text to Clipboard.
  2. Go to https://pastebin.mozilla.org/, paste the clipboard by right clicking in the large text area, select paste from the menu, change the retention period to expire in 28 days, use the Paste Snippet button to create a page containing your info, then copy the resulting URL (address) of the page created.
  3. Open a reply to this post, and paste the URL to your troubleshooting information you just copied.
  4. Please also provide results for the following test on your system
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX

creator: undercash

content:
Anti-virus software is most likely the culprit here.

Create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

Also, keep it working. http://kb.mozillazine.org/Keep_it_working_-_Thunderbird

And last but not least, backup your Thunderbird profile on a regular basis. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile
creator: christ1

creator: sfhowes

content:
Going back about a million years (it feels like it) Pdf was based on the Adobe postscript printer language, basically a vector based page layout language. So I am guessing that the issue is likely that the PDF's use a font that is simply not available on your device and is not embedded in the PDF. While it is not as common as 20 years ago, there are still font issues.

Usually when the squares instead of text, or even inverted question marks appear it is the font being used by the printer is not a UniCode font but the one in the document is.

The discussion on the apple forums would indicate others have encountered very similar issues and are being told similar things to what I have been saying. https://discussions.apple.com/thread/252963069?sortBy=best and https://discussions.apple.com/thread/1085137?sortBy=best
creator: MattAuSupport

Perhaps go to the web site. It was completely redecorated on the release of V115. https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/

As you have a 115 version, you already have the supernova version. That started with 115.0.0

I have no idea what specific item about 115.7 you are talking about. Could you be specific here.

I see all sorts of post in this and other forums where folk rant about how Thunderbird just does not work post update. I have been reading them for over 10 years and trying to help these folk. The one thing those posts almost all have in common is ignorance. Those that have a genuine bug in a new version generally ask a specific question. Not complain about the thing not working.

Just today I had someone tell me that you can not customize Thunderbirds toolbar because the option does not exist. That it was in Version 2 and every release since was apparently irrelevant.

content: If you have your accounts in TB set up as IMAP, do the same on your phone using whatever mail app you like. That will make the mail synced between TB and the phone.
creator: sfhowes

content: THANK YOU FOR YOUR REPLY :-). I'm still unclear how the transfer works? My TB is setup via a direct connection to Gmail, I believe they are SMTP? Please clarify?
creator: kedjohns

content: When accounts are IMAP, all devices display the messages that are on the mail server, and any action taken from any device is 'transferred' to the other device. For example, if a message is read or deleted in TB, it's also marked read or deleted on the phone. If a message is replied on the phone, it's marked as replied in TB, and the Sent folder in TB shows the reply.
creator: sfhowes

content: Do you have antivirus scanning mail? Try disabling that function. It was what was causing me to have almost identical lost connections. I changed antivirus to Microsoft defender built into Windows and have not looked back (and it saved me over $100 a year)
